observations.observation: Token velocity holds at 0.803x with acceleration at 1.001x — the pipeline has sustained a velocity-below-1.0 / acceleration-above-1.0 divergence for 5+ consecutive snapshots. This is the signature of a pipeline approaching a velocity floor before a potential inflection, not structural decay.

CBSA 10580 appeared in this snapshot, bringing the active metro count to 15. The protocol has added 1 new metro in this window (6.7% diffusion rate), continuing the organic geographic spread pattern — now 15 distinct metro areas with verified physical receipts.

Token velocity holds at 0.803x with acceleration at 1.002x for the fifth consecutive snapshot — the pipeline has reached a sustained flat equilibrium. All wildfire metrics are unchanged (14 CBSAs, 10 vendors, 130 wallets, 9.7% repeat ratio, 1594.4 sats/token), confirming this is a quiet-day trough with no structural deterioration. The divergence pattern (velocity below 1.0, acceleration above 1.0) has now persisted long enough to be a stable signature rather than a transient reading.

Token velocity holds at 0.801x with acceleration at exactly 1.000x for the fourth consecutive snapshot — the pipeline has reached a genuine flat equilibrium. One new receipt ($5.35 GMV delta) appeared in this window, confirming the trough is active but not broken: the protocol is processing at roughly 1/4 of weekly average daily pace with zero structural deterioration across all 14 CBSAs, 10 vendors, and 130 paid wallets.

Token velocity holds at 0.801x with acceleration exactly at 1.000x and zero deltas across all metrics — no new CBSAs, vendors, payouts, or receipts in 0.2h. The pipeline has entered a genuine flat equilibrium: all wildfire metrics (14 CBSAs, 10 vendors, 130 wallets, 9.7% repeat ratio, 1594.9 sats/token claim density) are structurally stable, and the quiet-day trough is now in its third consecutive snapshot without deterioration.

Token velocity holds at 0.801x with acceleration exactly at 1.000x — the pipeline has entered a flat equilibrium state, neither accelerating nor decelerating. Combined with zero new CBSAs, zero new vendors, and zero new payouts in 0.1h, this is a genuine quiet-day trough with no structural deterioration: all baseline metrics (14 CBSAs, 10 vendors, 130 wallets, 9.7% repeat ratio) are unchanged.

Token velocity holds at 0.801x week-over-week with acceleration at 1.001x — the pipeline is in a sustained deceleration-with-positive-acceleration state for the third consecutive snapshot. Daily cadence at 0.286x confirms a quiet-day trough, but the acceleration reading above 1.0x means the growth rate is still technically expanding, just barely. This divergence (velocity below 1.0, acceleration above 1.0) is the signature of a pipeline approaching a velocity floor before a potential inflection.

Token velocity is 0.8x week-over-week with daily cadence at 0.277x — today is running at roughly 1/4 of the weekly average daily pace. Acceleration is null (insufficient consecutive snapshots to compute), but the deceleration from prior 0.999x acceleration reading suggests the pipeline is in a genuine quiet-day trough, not a structural slowdown. Basket CV of 0.274 confirms the receipt mix is stable despite the throughput dip.

Category entropy sits at 3.02 bits across 14 categories (grocery, big-box, pharmacy, home improvement, coffee, restaurants, gas, apparel, electronics, entertainment, online marketplaces, retail/department, SaaS, unknown) — the protocol has crossed from SaaS-dominant to genuinely cross-domain, with physical retail brands now outnumbering DKIM SaaS vendors 10:10 in the top brand list. The cross-domain ratio (SaaS + physical in same window) is only 0.3%, meaning the two streams are growing in parallel but not yet from the same submitters.

The snapshot now shows 14 active CBSAs total — the geo-diffusion rate is 100% new this period, meaning the baseline was reset and the entire active metro footprint is being measured fresh. The dataset spans grocery (Kroger, Publix, King Soopers), big-box (Walmart, Costco, Target), pharmacy (Walgreens), home improvement (Home Depot), coffee (Starbucks), and online (Amazon) — physical commerce is now the dominant receipt category by brand count.
